title-group.article-title: Predicting the nonlinear response and progressive failure of composite laminates under tri-axial loading

article-meta.aff: 1US Army Research Laboratory, Aberdeen Proving Ground, MD, USA
2Center for Composite Materials, Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering and Department of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Delaware, USA
3Center for Composite Materials, University of Delaware, USA

author-notes.corresp: Travis A Bogetti, U.S. Army Research Laboratory, RDRL-WMM-B, Aberdeen Proving Ground, MD 21005-5066, USA Email: travis.a.bogetti.civ@mail.mil

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue: Evaluation of Theories for Predicting Failure in Polymer Composite Laminates Under 3-D States of Stress: Part A of the Second World-Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE-II)

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: As a part of the Second World-Wide Failure Exercise, a three-dimensional nonlinear maximum progressive strain model, based on laminate analysis, is employed to make blind predictions for 12 test cases representing failure envelopes and stress strain curves for isotropic, unidirectional, and multidirectional composite laminates. This approach allows for redistribution of ply stresses and differentiation of the various potential modes of failure. These cases include initial and final ply failure envelopes under tri-axial loading, as well as 3 cases, requiring nonlinear stress–strain analysis. Comparison of predictions with actual experimental data will be made in Part B of the Second World-Wide Failure Exercise.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Predicting the mechanical response and failure behavior of laminated composites is vitally important for efficient design in structural applications. Few would argue that predicting the effective laminate strain response to mechanical load is far easier than predicting the failure (or post failure) behavior of the laminate. It is not surprising that this subject has received a great wealth of attention since the early days of composite mechanics, see reviews in Chamis,1 Sandhu,2 Soni,3 Tsai4 and Nahas.5 Review of the literature reveals the broad spectrum of approaches that are employed in laminate failure prediction. With such a broad range of approaches, predictions for particular laminate configurations and loading are also likely to be widely varied.

To counter this, in the late 1990s and continuing until 2004, Hinton et al.6 conducted an international effort in order to assess the state-of-the-art in laminate response and failure prediction capabilities. The participants of this effort were tasked to perform failure envelope and nonlinear stress–strain predictions on carbon- and glass-reinforced epoxy laminates in the form of 14 different cases.7 The cases were provided without experimental data for the participants to predict, this encompassed Part A. Subsequently, in Part B, the experimental results were given to the participating teams to allow for any adjustments to be made before final comparisons. Nineteen failure theories, widely varying in approach, were represented in the exercise. The collective effort of the participants and review panel was known as the First Worldwide Failure Exercise (WWFE-I).8–12 The authors’ theory was one of several that received a high grade.11 Currently, a continuation of this effort, known as WWFE-II, is in effect. Once again, contributors will document their theoretical approach and will submit their predictions on 12 different loading cases. These cases include full three dimensional loading, a major difference from the first exercise. The details of the cases, material properties, and guidelines are published in a separate report. After the contributions are received, actual experimental results will be disseminated to the participants for comparison.

This article represents our model, based on Chou et al.13 and Bogetti et al.,14 and is employed to provide laminate response and failure predictions to the 12 laminate cases described in Part A of the WWFE-II. Subsequently, we plan to participate in Part B of the exercise and compare our predictions with the experimental data.

sec.title: Three-dimensional laminated media analysis
sec.p: In this work, the analytic model developed by Chou et al.13 is used to predict the effective laminate stress/strain response. It is also used to calculate ply-level stresses and strains during incremental loading for failure and strength prediction.14 The following section outlines the laminated media model upon which our analysis is based.

Chou et al.13 use a control volume approach to yield a closed-form solution to the problem of effective homogeneous property determination for a laminated media composed of individual layers. Unlike the works carried out in White and Angona,15 Postma,16 Rytov,17 Behrens18 and Salamon,19 which required the individual layers to be isotropic, Chou et al.13 permitted general anisotropy of the layers. The analysis is based on the assumptions that all interlaminar stresses are continuous across ply interfaces and that all in-plane strains are continuous through the thickness dimension of a representative volume element (i.e. a representative laminate configuration).

The following expression is used to represent the effective (i.e. homogeneous) stress/strain constitutive relationship for an N-layered laminate (Figure 1) (1)σi *¯=Cij *¯ɛj *¯ for(i,j=1,2,3,4,5,6) Figure 1.
Laminate configuration.

The barred notation is used to denote that the relationship applies in the global x-y-z coordinate system of the laminate. The asterisk superscript is used here to denote the ‘average’ or effective laminate stress and strain quantities. In-plane strains are assumed uniform (i.e. constant within each ply) and equal to the effective strains of the laminate. Mathematically, this is expressed as (2)ɛi k¯=ɛi *¯ for(i=1,2,6;k=1,2,…,N) where ɛi k¯ represents the strain in the kth ply of the laminate (see ply numbering convention in Figure 1). To ensure stress continuity across ply interfaces, all ply stress components associated with the out-of-plane direction (i.e. z-direction) are assumed uniform and equal to the corresponding effective stresses in the laminate. Mathematically, this is expressed as (3)σi k¯=σi *¯ for (i=3,4,5;k=1,2,…,N) where σi k¯ represents the stress in the kth ply of the laminate.

All remaining effective laminate strains and stresses are assumed to be the volume average of all their corresponding ply strain and stress components, respectively. Mathematically, these assumptions are expressed as (4)ɛi *¯=∑k=1 NVkɛi k¯ for(i=3,4,5) and (5)σi *¯=∑k=1 NVkσi k¯ for(i=1,2,6) where Vk is the ratio of the original (i.e. undeformed) volume of the kth ply over the original volume of the entire laminate. The constitutive equation for each ply in the laminate is written below (equation (6)) using the superscript notation. (6)σi k¯=Cij k¯ɛj k¯ for(i,j=1,2,3,4,5,6;k=1,2,…,N)

Equations (1) to (6) represent 12 N + 6 linear algebraic equations with 12N + 12 unknowns. Solution to equations (1) to (6) yields the following effective three-dimensional stress/strain constitutive relation, which can be used as an equivalent (i.e. homogeneous) representation for the laminated media where the coefficients in the laminate stiffness matrix, Cij k¯, are given by (7)σi k¯=Cij k¯ɛj k¯ for(i,j=1,2,3,4,5,6;k=1,2,…,N) (8)Cij *¯=Cji *¯=0 for(i=1,2,3,6;j=4,5) and (9)σi k¯=Cij k¯ɛj k¯ for(i,j=1,2,3,4,5,6;k=1,2,…,N) where (10)Δk=|C44 k¯ C45 k¯C54 k¯ C55 k¯|=C44 k¯ C55 k¯-C45 k¯ C54 k¯
The effective stress/strain constitutive relation for the laminated media is therefore given by equations (1) and (7) to (10).

In determining the individual ply-level stresses and strains, the assumption is made that the applied mechanical loading on the laminated media (σi *¯) is known, uniform, and represents the ‘average’ or ‘effective’ stress acting on the representative laminate configuration. The associated ‘effective’ or ‘smeared’ laminate strains (ɛi *¯) can be obtained directly from the inversion of equation (1). From the assumption made in equation (2), all in-plane strain values (defined in the global x-y-z coordinate system) for plies 1 through N are therefore known. Similarly, from the assumption made in equation (3), all out-of-plane stresses for plies 1 through N are known (also defined in the global x-y-z coordinate system). The out-of-plane ply strains and in-plane ply stresses remain to be determined.
Sun and Liao20 derived the following expression for determination of the remaining out-of plane ply strains (11)σi k¯=Cij k¯ɛj k¯ for(i,j=1,2,3,4,5,6;k=1,2,…,N)

Once all of the ply strains are known, the remaining in-plane ply stresses can be calculated straightforwardly through the following relation (12)[σ1 k¯σ2 k¯σ6 k¯]=[C11 k¯ C12 k¯ C13 k¯ C14 k¯ C15 k¯ C16 k¯C21 k¯ C22 k¯ C23 k¯ C24 k¯ C25 k¯ C26 k¯C61 k¯ C62 k¯ C63 k¯ C64 k¯ C65 k¯ C66 k¯][ɛ1 k¯ɛ2 k¯ɛ3 k¯ɛ4 k¯ɛ5 k¯ɛ6 k¯]

sec.title: Defining nonlinear lamina constitutive relations
sec.p: Material nonlinearity in our laminate analysis is accounted for on the lamina or ply level. The nonlinear lamina constitutive relations (i.e. stress versus strain relations) for each of the principal lamina directions are defined with the Ramberg–Osgood equation.21 For the treatment of unidirectional lamina in our three-dimensional analysis, this would include the fiber direction (1), in-plane transverse direction (2), transverse normal direction (3), interlaminar shear directions (23 and 13), and the in-plane shear direction (12).
The Ramberg–Osgood equation provides an expression for stress written explicitly in terms of strain and three unique parameters (13)σ=Eoɛ(1+(Eoɛσo)n)1n.

Here Eo is the initial modulus, σo is the asymptotic stress level and n is a shape parameter for the stress versus strain curve. Figure 2 graphically illustrates the significance of these parameters with a typical nonlinear stress versus strain relationship. Figure 2.
Ramberg–Osgood parameter definition.

For computational considerations, it is desired to define the instantaneous or tangent lamina stiffness as a continuous function of strain. Taking the derivative of equation (13) with respect to strain, the following expression is obtained (14)Et=dσdɛ=Eo(1+(Eoɛσo)n)1+1n where Et is the instantaneous or tangent lamina stiffness modulus expressed explicitly in terms of strain and the three Ramberg–Osgood parameters.

A unique set of Ramberg–Osgood parameters for each of the principal directions in the lamina is required. A fitting routine programmed in MATLAB was implemented to find the Ramberg–Osgood parameters which most realistically represent the stress/strain response for each of the six materials used in the study. A total of six curves were fitted for each of the six materials provided by the organizers of the WWFE-II. As an example, the data fit to equation (13) is illustrated in Figure 3 for the nonlinear 12-shear direction stress/strain response of the S-glass/Epoxy2 material. A full account of all the Ramberg–Osgood parameters used in our analysis is provided in the Results section of this article. Figure 3.
Ramberg-Osgood parameters fit to S-glass/Epoxy 2 data.

sec.title: Incremental approach (solution strategy)
sec.p:
The nonlinear response of the laminate is generated through the summation of piece-wise linear increments in stress over a pre-established load schedule. An incremental form of equation (1) is used to determine the linear increments in laminate stress and strain. The laminate stiffness matrix is updated at the end of each stress increment (based on all current ply strain levels) during the incremental loading strategy. The schematic presented in Figure 4 provides a mathematical representation of the incremental loading strategy for an arbitrary laminate. Figure 4.
Incremental laminate loading methodology.

Assume that at point a, corresponding to the end of the nth stress increment, the strain and stress state of the laminate is known (ɛ*¯j n,σ*¯i n). From this point, the objective is to determine the strain and stress state at point b or (ɛ*¯j n+1,σ*¯i n+1). The effective laminate stiffness matrix at the end of stress increment n, Cij¯n, is computed from an incremental form of the laminated media model constitutive relation, equation (1). With the increment in load defined, Δσ*¯i n, the corresponding increment in laminate strain, Δɛ*¯j n, is calculated from an inverse form of equation (1) (15)σi k¯=Cij k¯ɛj k¯ for(i,j=1,2,3,4,5,6;k=1,2,…,N)

Individual ply stress and strain increments are calculated according to the equations presented previously. A cumulative summation is maintained to track the total stress and strain levels in each ply of the laminate. The tangent modulus values for each ply and material direction are calculated according to equation (14) and used in the determination of the laminate stiffness matrix for the next laminate stress increment calculation.

The entire nonlinear response for the laminate is obtained by the cumulative sum of all stress and strain increments throughout the entire stress loading history. The implementation of a progressive ply failure methodology into this incremental loading strategy is described in the next section.

sec.title: Lamina failure methodology
sec.p:
Failure of individual plies and their effect on the overall laminate response during incremental loading are accounted for in our analysis. Our ply failure predictions are based on the well-established maximum strain failure criterion.5,22 The maximum strain failure criterion predicts that a material will fail when the strain in any direction exceeds its corresponding allowable level. The principal ply strains (ε1, ε2, ε3, ε4, ε5 and ε6) are compared to their corresponding maximum strain allowables in Table 1. Table 1.
Strain conditions and failure modes
Strain allowables Failure mode
ε1 > 0 and if ε1 > Y1T Fiber tension
ε1 < 0 and if |ε1| > Y1C Fiber compression
ε2 > 0 and if ε2 > Y2T Transverse tension
ε2 < 0 and if |ε2| > Y2C Transverse compression
ε3 > 0 and if ε3 > Y3T Transverse tension
ε3 < 0 and if |ε3| > Y3C Transverse compression
|ε4| > Y23 Interlaminar shear
|ε5| > Y13 Interlaminar shear
|ε6| > Y12 In-plane shear

In Table 1, Y1T is the maximum tensile strain in the 1-direction (longitudinal), Y1C is the maximum compressive strain in the 1-direction, Y2T is the maximum tensile strain in the 2-direction (transverse), Y2C is the maximum compressive strain in the 2-direction, Y3T is the maximum tensile strain in the 3-direction (out-of-plane), Y3C is the maximum compressive strain in the 3-direction, Y23 is the maximum shear strain in the 23-plane, Y13 is the maximum shear strain in the 13-plane, and Y12 is the maximum shear strain in the 12-plane. Failure under longitudinal compression does not take into fiber instability or fiber microbuckling, see Lee and Soutis23 and Wisnom et al.24 for a thorough understanding of these phenomena.

As the laminate is loaded and laminate strains develop, the individual ply strains are monitored. When ply failure is predicted in any ply, according to the maximum strain failure criteria, the incremental loading to that point is stopped and the entire laminate stress versus strain response is recorded. The modulus associated with the particular mode of failure (i.e. one of the nine modes listed in Table 1) in the failed ply is then reduced to an insignificant value (as well as the associated Poisson’s ratio), and the incremental loading strategy is repeated from the beginning (all stresses and strains are set to zero). The loading procedure is continued until the next failure in a ply is detected. The corresponding modulus value is again discounted, the laminate response is recorded, and the procedure is repeated. This progressive ply failure response is repeated until final failure is determined, which is assumed when the laminate looses sufficient stiffness such that it cannot carry any load without undergoing an arbitrarily excessive amount of deformation (say greater than 5% strain). This strain value could be very conservative as, for instance, off-axis laminates such as (+45°/−45°)s under uniaxial tension can exceed 5% and axial failure strains of more than 14% have been reported.25

The entire laminate response is determined by the stress versus strain response up to the point of failure, and then the load is assumed to drop to the level of the subsequent stress versus strain curve response. The load path then continues until failure and drops again. This methodology essentially corresponds to progressive ply failure where the load in failure plies is redistributed to adjacent plies under a displacement controlled load path history.

The current progressive analysis is simple. Other sophisticated models, e.g. Kashtalyan and Soutis,26–28 can deal with other important issues. For instance, it is known that,26–28 although initially, before any damage occurs, one may start with a balanced and symmetric lay-up, once damage happens in a ply (say matrix cracking), the laminate is not any more symmetric and balanced, especially in off-axis dominated lay-ups; the Poisson’s ratio may increase and the non-symmetry introduced due to damage may cause coupling between stretching and shear.

sec.title: Thermal residual stresses
sec.p: Thermal residual stresses resulting from thermal expansion mismatch in adjacent plies in the laminates during cool down from the stress-free state at the cure temperature were not accounted for in the predictions. Their actual calculation follows straightforwardly from the analysis derivation described in the previous section. For completeness, however, a full description of their determination is given elsewhere.14 It is acknowledged that the inclusion of thermal residual stresses will have some effect on the ultimate laminate strength predictions. The exact effect, however, will depend on the specific laminate architecture and loading considered.
It should also be noted here that moisture can also have a significant effect on damage initiation, growth and final fracture.29

sec.title: Analysis execution
sec.p: The aforementioned laminate analysis and progressive ply failure methodology has been programmed into a FORTRAN-based software code entitled LAM3DNL. The LAM3DNL code employs a user-friendly database format for input of laminate architectures, lamina properties, and failure parameters.14 Output from the code includes the effective laminate stress and strain files as well as a failure assessment summary file that identifies all ply failures that occur during a laminate response prediction program run. To expedite this process, a program based in MATLAB was developed to automatically run LAM3DNL. This program also recorded, analyzed, and displayed the failure envelope or stress–strain graphs.

sec.title: Test case summary
sec.p:
As presented by Kaddour and Hinton,30 the 12 different load case predictions are described in this section. These cases are divided into three separate groups (a) biaxial failure envelopes of pure resin or unidirectional laminates under multi-axial loading, (b) biaxial failure envelopes of multi-directional laminates, and (c) stress–strain curves of laminates under uniaxial and multi-axial loading. The entire summary of provided cases is listed in Table 2, including the materials, layup configurations, and loading cases, see Kaddour and Hinton30 for further details. Table 2.
Details of the laminates and loading cases.30
Loading case Laminate lay-up Material Description of loading cases
1 Resin MY750 epoxy σx vs. σz (with σy = σz)
2 0° T300/PR319 τ12 vs. σ2 (with σ1 = σ2 = σ3)
3 0° T300/PR319 γ12 vs. σ2 (with σ1 = σ2 = σ3)
4 0° T300/PR319 Shear stress–strain curves (τ12 − γ12) for σ1=σ2 = σ3 = −600 MPa
5 90° E-glass/MY750 σ2 vs. σ3 (with σ1 = σ3)
6 0° S-Glass/Epoxy2 σ1 vs. σ3 (with σ2 = σ3)
7 0° AS/Epoxy1 σ1 vs. σ3 (with σ2 = σ3)
8 ±35° E-glass/MY750 σy vs. σz (with σx = σz)
9 ±35° E-glass/MY750 Stress–strain curves (σy − εx and σy − εy) at σx = σz = −100 MPa
10 (0°/90°/±45°)s IM7/8551-7 τyz vs. σz (with σx = σy = 0)
11 (0°/90°)s IM7/8551-7 τyz vs. σz (with σx = σy = 0)
12 (0°/90°)s IM7/8551-7 Stress–strain curves (σz − εx, σz − εy and σz − εz) for σx = σy = 0

sec.title: Lamina properties and failure allowables
sec.p: Lamina material properties and failure allowables were provided by Kaddour and Hinton.30 Upon examining the data provided, we assume that the longitudinal response in the lamina is linear. The interlaminar shear modulus is also assumed linear according to G23 = E2/2(1 + ν23). For MY750 resin properties needed for Case 1, several assumptions are made. The resin is assumed to be isotropic, with a caveat. The current iteration of the theory does not allow for separate tensile and compressive properties, therefore a modification to the failure criteria is needed to achieve the larger compressive failure strength.

For those properties that are nonlinear, we fit the data provided to the Ramberg–Osgood equation for input into the analysis. Since the longitudinal moduli are assumed linear, we modify the parameters of the Ramberg–Osgood equation to reflect this. Using the initial modulus provided (Eo), we set the asymptotic stress level and shape factor (σo and n) to arbitrarily high values. This ensures that the response remains linear until well after the ultimate strain level is achieved.

sec.title: Interpretation of failure envelope graphs
sec.p:
The three possible envelope states are shown in an example failure envelope in Figure 5. First, in section 1 the final and initial failures overlap, i.e. initial failure is final failure. This is indicated by the solid square surrounded by an open circle. In this section, both the square and circle are the same color, which is not the case in section 2. If the initial and final envelopes coincide, but have different square and circle colors, it indicates that there is simultaneous failure. If the material has the same properties in the 2 and 3 directions and the same loading is applied in the 2 and 3 directions, it will reach failure in both those directions at the same time. To indicate this on the graph, the square will be one color corresponding to a failure mode and the circle will be the color of the other mode. The order of these colors is irrelevant. Finally, in section 3 the initial (blue dotted line) and final (solid red line) failure envelope are not coincident. The data markers for final failure remain as solid squares while the initial failure markers are solid circles. Figure 5.
Example failure envelope.

sec.title: Biaxial failure envelopes of pure resin or unidirectional laminates under multi-axial loading (Cases 1–7 excluding 4)
sec.p:
The biaxial failure stress envelope (σx vs. σz) is shown in Figure 6 for Case 1 of the MY750 resin under triaxial loading (i.e. with (σy = σz)). Since the material is modeled as a single layer or lamina, the predicted initial and final failures are coincident. The simultaneous transverse loading in the y- and z-directions induces Poisson effects that allow the material to reach higher stress values than could be achieved under uniaxial load conditions. The material’s tensile strength is 80 MPa, but the simultaneous loading condition allows it to reach 125 MPa. Table 5 compares the final failure strength of each unidirectional case with the failure allowables of the material used in that case. These measurements are taken along the intercepts in order to facilitate comparison. Figure 6.
Case 1 – biaxial failure envelope (σx vs. σz) of the MY750 resin under triaxial loading (σy = σz). Table 5.
Comparison of predictions to material allowables
Stress at Stress at Stress at Stress at
Case Material 0° 90° 180° 270°
1 MY750 124 81 −118 −121
Allowable MY750 80 80 −120 −120
2 T300/PR319 50 97 −256
Allowable T300/PR319 40 97 −125
3 T300/PR319 50 8.68* −256
Allowable T300/PR319 40 8.60* −125
5 E-Glass/MY750 40 40 −97 −100
Allowable E-Glass/MY750 40 40 −145 −145
6 S-Glass/Epoxy2 86 1698 −309 −455
Allowable S-Glass/Epoxy2 50 1700 −180 −1150
7 AS/Epoxy1 75 1988 −291 −1498
Allowable AS/Epoxy1 38 1990 −150 −1500
*
Indicates strain.

Cases 2 and 3, shown in Figures 7 and 8, respectively, are the biaxial failure envelopes of unidirectional T300/PR319 under shear and triaxial loading. Case 3 is a slight variation on Case 2 as it shows the in-plane shear strain versus transverse stress as opposed to the in-plane shear stress versus transverse stress, thus creating a stress–strain envelope. As with Case 1, being unidirectional laminates, the initial and final failures are coincident. The rectangular shape of the envelope is characteristic of the maximum strain-based criteria used in the failure model. Because the lamina has the same properties in the 2 and 3 directions, and is loaded symmetrically in all directions, the failure along the vertical sections of the rectangle is in the 2 and 3 principle directions (Y2T/Y3T and Y2C/Y3C). As expected, the top section of the envelope is indicating a shear failure mode at stress and strain levels near the allowable values. In these cases, the tensile and compressive failure strengths of 50 and −256 MPa exceed their respective allowables of 40 and −125 MPa. The reason this occurs is due to the triaxial loading that induces lower strains through Poisson’s effect. Figure 7.
Case 2 – biaxial failure envelope (τ12 vs. σ2) of [0°] T300/PR319 laminate under triaxial loading (σ1 = σ2 = σ3). Figure 8.
Case 3 – biaxial failure envelope (γ12 vs. σ2) of [0°] T300/PR319 laminate under triaxial loading (σ1 = σ2 = σ3).

In Figure 9, the results of Case 5 are shown. A 90° laminate of E-glass/MY750 is subjected to transverse loading in the 2 and 3 directions, with loads in the 3 direction equal to the 1 direction. In quadrant 1, the failure mode transitions from through thickness tensile failure (Y3T) to transverse tensile failure (Y2T). This failure mode continues into quadrant 2 and, due to Poisson’s effect, carries over into quadrant 3. The majority of failure in the third quadrant is compressive failure (Y3C) in the principal directions of the load, which is expected. Poisson’s effect once again changes the failure mode from compression (Y2C) to tension (Y3T) as the envelope transitions into the forth quadrant. While the failure mode remains the same in the forth quadrant, it changes from Poisson’s induced through thickness failure to tensile load induced failure. The material is in line with its failure allowables in the tensile state, but due to the larger Poisson’s ratio (ν23) failure is induced earlier than expected in the compressive directions. Figure 9.
Case 5 – biaxial failure envelope (σ2 vs. σ3) for [90°] E-Glass/MY750 laminate under triaxial loading (σ1 = σ3).

The biaxial failure envelope for a 0° S-Glass/Epoxy2 laminate subjected to longitudinal and simultaneous transverse loading is investigated in Case 6 (Figure 10). As with the previous cases, the initial and final failures coincide. The shape of the envelope is best described as quadrilateral. Along the top side, the material fails as expected, in longitudinal tension, Y1T. The failure transitions from longitudinal compression (Y1C) to transverse tension failure (Y3T) due to Poisson’s effect along the bottom of the envelope. This effect is reflected in the values in Table 5 for this case, where there is a difference between the failure stress and allowable in the compressive directions. Along the left side of the envelope, the material fails simultaneously in both transverse directions (Y2C/Y3C). Because the material has a weaker tensile strength in the 3 direction, the right side of the envelope is dominated by transverse tensile failure in the 3 direction. Figure 10.
Case 6 – biaxial failure envelope (σ1 vs. σ3) of [0°] S-Glass/Epoxy 2 with triaxial loading (σ2 = σ3).

Case 7, that is shown in Figure 11, is very similar to Case 6, with its only difference is the material being evaluated. The same description of the failure envelope holds true in this case and Case 6, but with two main differences. This material reaches longitudinal compressive failure, Y1C, before Poisson’s effects cause transverse tensile failure, Y2T/Y3T. The shape of the envelope along its lower section reflects this change. Also, because the material has the same tensile strength in the 2 and 3 directions, the material fails simultaneously (Y2T/Y3T) in those directions along the right side of the envelope. Figure 11.
Case 7 – biaxial failure envelope (σ1 vs. σ3) of [0°] AS/Epoxy 1 with triaxial loading (σ2 = σ3).

sec.title: Biaxial failure envelopes of multi-directional laminates (Cases 8, 10 and 11)
sec.p:
In Figure 12, E-Glass/MY750 in a ±35 lay-up is examined in a biaxial failure envelope (σy vs. σz) with σx = σz. Case 8 can be compared directly to Case 5 because the same material and loading conditions are used, with the main difference being the lay-up. The overall size of the envelope is larger in this case than in Case 5. As with Case 5, the description of the failure mode is similar to this case. The major difference between the two cases is the separation of the final and initial failure envelopes in the second quadrant and parts of the first and third quadrants. This region has shear dominated failure (Y12) in the final failure envelope, due to the lay-up direction being off-axis of the load direction. Figure 12.
Case 8 – biaxial failure envelope (σy vs. σz) for [±35°] E-Glass/MY750 laminate under triaxial loading (σx = σz).

Cases 10 and 11, shown in Figures 13 and 14 respectively, deal with the biaxial failure envelope of a IM7/8551-7 laminate under shear and through thickness (τyz vs. σz) loading. The lay-up for Cases 10 and 11 are [0°/90°/±45°]s and [0°/90°]s, respectively. For both cases, the final and initial failures occur at the same time. Similar to the previous cases that had shear loading, these cases have the typical rectangular shape. The vertical sections in both cases fail, as expected, in the Z mode of tension (Y3T) and compression (Y3C). When the shear loading becomes the dominating term, both structures fail in Y23 shear. The differences between the two cases are when and how high the shear failure occurs. The ±45° plies in Case 10 allow the laminate to resist a slightly higher amount of shear loading (65 MPa) before failure when compared to Case 11 (62 MPa), which does not have these plies. Figure 13.
Case 10 – biaxial failure envelope (τyz vs. σz) for [0°/90°/±45°]s IM7/8551-7 laminate. Figure 14.
Case 11 – biaxial failure envelope (τyz vs. σz) for [0°/90°]s IM7/8551-7 laminate.

sec.title: Stress–strain curves of laminates under uniaxial and multi-axial loading (Cases 4, 9 and 12)
sec.p:
Case 4, seen in Figure 15, is the shear stress–strain curve of a T300/PR319 unidirectional laminate under hydrostatic compression. The material is compressed up to −600 MPa in all principle directions and then shear stress (τ12) is applied until failure, which is Y12 failure. The hydrostatic loading of the material causes no shear stresses, so the shear stress–strain curve is similar to that of the material with no initial loading. Figure 15.
Case 4 – shear stress–strain curves (τ12 − γ12) of [0°] T300/PR319 laminate after symmetric loading of σ1 = σ2 = σ3 = −600 MPa.

The stress–strain curves (σy − εx and σy − εy) of E-Glass/MY750 in a ±35° lay-up are examined in Case 9 and shown in Figure 16. In this case, the material is first compressed hydrostatically up to −100 MPa, after which the load is only applied in the y direction. The strains are negative under the initial compression loading, as expected. When load is applied further in the y direction, the nonlinear stress–strain relationship continues in that direction until Y2C failure occurs. Due to Poisson’s effect, the strain in the x direction increases as a result of the compressive transverse loading. Figure 16.
Case 9 – stress–strain curves (σy − εx and σy − εy) for a [±35°] E-Glass/MY750 laminate with initial σy = σx = σz = − 100 MPa loading, followed by σy loading until failure.

A laminate with lay-up [0°/90°] symmetric IM7/8551-7 is subjected to purely through-thickness loading (σz) is examined in Case 12. The strains εx, εy and εz are shown with respect to the stress below in Figure 17. The strains in the x and y direction are caused by Poisson’s effect from the larger strain in the direction of the applied load. The material fails in the through thickness tensile direction, Y3T. Because the failure strain is relatively low in this direction, its response is contained within the region in which the material is close to linear. Figure 17.
Case 12 – stress–strain curves (σz − εx, σz − εy and σz − εz) for [0°/90°]s IM7/8551-7 laminate.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Theoretical predictions of 12 challenging test cases, proposed by the WWFE-II, have been made using a model based on an incremental formulation of a well-established 3D laminated media analysis. A progressive ply failure methodology and nonlinear lamina constitutive relations are used and the model allowed a discrimination of the various potential modes of failure, including those encountered in the through-thickness direction.

The 3D laminated media theory that is used here is capable of analyzing the through-thickness response of laminates. The theory in use is easily adapted for implementation in the design and failure assessment of composite structures.33

The predictions from the current modes have been compared in Kaddour and Hinton,31 with those generated by other participants of the WWFE-II, representing some 11 other competing theories. Comparisons with the experimental data will be made and published for Part B of WWFE-II.32

One of the limitations of the present approach, based on maximum strain failure criterion, is that it may not be able to predict and model growth/propagation of damage in composite laminates, due to its limited post failure capability. Currently, there is a huge amount of effort being put in by the community to develop fracture mechanics based models (for example, cohesive zone models) for such cases. The Third Word-Wide Failure Exercise,25 contains some 12 different methods/models that may be used for that purpose.

The current model deals with material characterization. Its applicability has not been assessed here for examining specimens with free edges (flat, rectangular plates) or cylindrical ones where there are less free-edge effects.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: None declared.
